questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Exodus 3:1-15 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the burning bush (v.2) and the phrase 'I AM WHO I AM' (v.14).
tips: Notice the bush burns but is not consumed (v.2)
Pay attention to Moses' initial hesitation and God's immediate response (v.4-5)
The phrase 'I AM WHO I AM' (v.14) is the divine name that reveals God's self-existence

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God is speaking to, WHAT God reveals about Israel, WHERE this happens, and WHY God is acting (using 5W+H).
tips: Moses is the one called by God at Horeb
God reveals He has seen Israel's affliction in Egypt and will deliver them
The location is Horeb (Mount Hor) in a burning bush

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the burning bush (v.2), God's name 'I AM WHO I AM' (v.14), or the promise of a land flowing with milk and honey (v.16)?
tips: The bush that burns without being consumed (v.2) pictures God's presence that is both active and sustaining
The phrase 'I AM WHO I AM' (v.14) is the ultimate self-revelation of God's eternal nature
The promise of a land flowing with milk and honey (v.16) shows God's provision for the future of Israel

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God through this passage?
tips: God is the active, sovereign God who sees the suffering of His people and will deliver them
The name 'I AM WHO I AM' (v.14) reveals God's self-existence and covenant relationship with Israel
Moses is called to be the instrument of God's deliverance (v.10)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The burning bush, the phrase 'I AM WHO I AM', or the promise of a land flowing with milk and honey?
tips: The burning bush (v.2) is a miraculous sign that God is present without destruction, which is a unique sign of divine encounter
The phrase 'I AM WHO I AM' (v.14) is not a title but a statement of God's self-existence and eternal nature
The promise of a land flowing with milk and honey (v.16) is a future promise that Israel will be free and have a new land, which is both physical and spiritual

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you respond to God's self-revelation as the burning bush (v.2) in your current situation?
tips: When you feel overwhelmed, remember that God is present and not consuming you (v.2)
Practice declaring God's name 'I AM WHO I AM' (v.14) as a reminder of His eternal nature
Identify one area where God is calling you to be a deliverer and take a small step this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about God's self-revelation as the burning bush and His promise to deliver.
tips: Thank God that He sees your affliction and is not consumed by your struggles
Ask for the courage to be the instrument of His deliverance in your current situation
Pray that you will know God's name 'I AM WHO I AM' in the midst of trials

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Exodus 4:1-31 aloud, paying attention to Moses' objections in verses 8-12 and the signs described in verses 3-9
tips: Note the repetition of 'I am not able' (v. 10) and Moses' concern about his speech (v. 10)
Listen for the tension in the dialogue between God and Moses in verses 10-12
Pay attention to the specific signs: staff to serpent (v. 3), hand healing (v. 6), water to blood (v. 7)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Moses and God), WHAT (God gives signs and appoints Aaron), WHERE (in Egypt), and WHY (to convince Pharaoh to release the Israelites)
tips: Include Moses' initial reluctance and the three signs
Note that God appoints Aaron as the spokesman because Moses lacks confidence in speech
Mention the incident with Zipporah and the uncircumcised son on the way back to Egypt

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the staff turning into a serpent (v. 3), the hand healing (v. 6), or the confrontation with Zipporah (v. 22-23)?
tips: The staff becoming a serpent is a powerful sign that shows God's authority and the power of His word
Zipporah's quick action to circumcise her son shows the importance of covenant obedience in a moment of crisis
The hand healing is a sign that God can heal the leprous condition, which was a sign of spiritual uncleanness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was God trying to communicate to Moses (and the Israelites) through this passage about the signs and the appointment of Aaron?
tips: God is showing that He is the ultimate authority and that He can work miracles to prove Moses' message
The signs are meant to authenticate Moses as God's messenger and to overcome the objections of the Israelites
The partnership with Aaron highlights the importance of having a spokesperson for the mission

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The three signs, why God appoints Aaron, or the significance of the uncircumcised son?
tips: The staff turning into a serpent is a sign that is both a physical miracle and a foreshadowing of the bronze serpent in Numbers and the cross
In the context of ancient Egypt, the leprous hand being healed was a sign of God's power over disease and spiritual impurity
The uncircumcision of the son was a serious issue in the covenant, as it was a sign of the Abrahamic covenant

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of signs and wonders to your life? Consider the three signs in Exodus 4 and how they were used to overcome objections.
tips: When you face objections to your faith or mission, ask God for signs that can authenticate your message
Like Aaron, find a partner in mission who can speak on your behalf when you lack confidence
Practice the covenant obedience in small ways, like the quick action of Zipporah

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the signs that authenticate His messengers and ask for the courage to face objections.
tips: Thank God for the signs that authenticate His messengers
Pray for courage to face objections and to be willing to perform the covenant rites
Ask God to help you find a partner in mission (like Aaron) when you lack confidence

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Exodus 5:1-21 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Moses and Pharaoh and the increasing oppression.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'Let my people go' (v.1, 2, 3)
Pay attention to Pharaoh's question 'Who is the LORD?' (v.2) and his increasing demands (v.5-10)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize who is involved, what happens, where it occurs, and why Pharaoh increases the burden.
tips: Include the demand for bricks without straw (v.5-6)
Note the beating of Hebrew foremen and their blame on Moses (v.7-10)
Moses' complaint to God about the oppression (v.22-23)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider Pharaoh's question (v.2), the beating of foremen (v.7-10), or Moses' complaint (v.22)?
tips: Pharaoh's question 'Who is the LORD?' (v.2) - the identity of God is the root issue
The Hebrew foremen being beaten (v.7-10) - the human cost of oppression
Moses' complaint 'Why have you done evil to this people?' (v.22) - the emotional depth of suffering

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God and the situation in Egypt?
tips: God is the true God and the deliverer, while Pharaoh is the false god and oppressor
Deliverance comes after hardship and increased oppression
This shows the pattern of suffering before breakthrough in the Christian life

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The increasing oppression? The role of the foremen? The identity of the LORD?
tips: Why does Pharaoh increase the burden? (cultural context: Pharaoh was trying to control the Israelites, but this shows his resistance to God's will)
The Hebrew foremen are beaten: they were the intermediaries, not the Israelites directly
The phrase 'the LORD' (v.2) - in Hebrew, this is a personal name of God, but Pharaoh doesn't know who He is

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Identify one area this week where you are facing increased pressure or opposition (like Pharaoh's burden) and pray for God's deliverance.
tips: Think about a situation where you are being oppressed by a 'Pharaoh' (e.g., circumstances, people)
Pray for God to strengthen you to cry out for His deliverance
Practice 'crying out' to God in your struggles

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being the true God who will deliver us from oppression. Ask for courage to cry out when you face hardship.
tips: Thank God that He is the true God who will deliver us from oppression
Pray for courage to cry out to God when you face hardship
Ask God to help you not harden your heart like Pharaoh

chapters.chapterTitle: Plagues of Frogs, Gnats, and Flies

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Exodus 8:1-30 aloud, focusing on the progression of plagues and Pharaoh's responses.
tips: Notice the repetition of Pharaoh's hardening heart in verses 15, 21, 29
Pay attention to the magicians' failure to replicate the gnats (v.17)
Highlight the phrase 'the finger of God' (v.19)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Pharaoh, Moses, Egyptian magicians, Israelites) does WHAT (Pharaoh hardens his heart, Moses commands plagues) WHERE (Egypt) and WHY (to force Pharaoh to release Israel).
tips: Include the frogs as the second plague (v.1-12)
Note the gnats as the third plague (v.13-17) where magicians fail
Mention the flies as the fourth plague (v.18-20) that spare Goshen

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the frogs (v.1-12), the magicians' failure with gnats (v.17), or the flies and Goshen's protection (v.18-20)?
tips: The magicians' admission that 'this is the finger of God' (v.19) shows divine power beyond human control
The phrase 'the land of Goshen' being spared (v.20) highlights God's protection for His people
Pharaoh's repeated hardening of heart (v.15,21,29) illustrates the danger of false repentance

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God's power and character through these plagues?
tips: God's judgments are escalating and distinct from Egypt to show His authority
The protection of Goshen demonstrates God's faithfulness to His chosen people
The 'finger of God' (v.19) points to God's active, sovereign presence

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The progression of plagues, the meaning of 'finger of God', or the hardening of Pharaoh's heart?
tips: In ancient Egypt, frogs were associated with impurity and disease, so God's use of frogs was a sign of judgment against Egypt's false gods
'Finger of God' is a Hebrew phrase (yad Adonai) meaning God's active, direct intervention, not a divine sign like in later times
Pharaoh's hardening heart (v.15,21,29) shows his refusal to acknowledge God's power despite visible plagues

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the distinction between God's protection and judgment to your life this week?
tips: Identify areas where you are 'Goshen' (protected) and where you are 'Egypt' (under judgment) in your life
Pray for the strength to resist the hardening of your heart when facing trials
Ask God to reveal how He is protecting you in your current situation

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about God's protection for His people and the danger of hardening the heart.
tips: Thank God for His faithfulness to protect His people (like Goshen)
Ask for the courage to avoid hardening your heart in the face of trials
Pray for Pharaoh's example of false repentance to be a warning against our own unbelief

chapters.chapterTitle: Plagues on Livestock, Boils, and Hail

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Exodus 9:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the tension in Pharaoh's responses and the progression of the plagues.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'Let my people go' (v.1, v.3)
Pay attention to Pharaoh's hardening heart (v.6, v.12)
The phrase 'the LORD said' (v.1, v.3) shows God's authority

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is affected, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY God sends these plagues.
tips: Pharaoh's refusal to let Israel go leads to God's judgment on Egypt
The livestock plague (v.5) shows God's protection of Israelites
The hail plague (v.11) destroys crops and kills those outside

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out? Consider: Pharaoh's confession (v.12), the hail's destruction (v.11), or the magicians' inability to stand (v.9)?
tips: Pharaoh's confession of sin ('I have sinned') shows temporary repentance but his hardening heart (v.12) reveals his sinfulness
The hail is described as 'the worst in Egypt's history' (v.11) - a vivid image of God's power
The magicians' inability to stand before Moses (v.9) shows the superiority of God's power over Egyptian magic

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God's character and purpose through these plagues?
tips: God's judgment on Egypt (the land of the gods) to demonstrate His sovereignty
The distinction between Israelites (protected) and Egyptians (judged) shows God's election
Pharaoh's hardening heart (v.12) illustrates how sin leads to further judgment

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The sequence of plagues, the meaning of 'boils', or why Ph's hardening heart?
tips: The term 'boils' (v.8) refers to a severe skin disease that would be painful and contagious, showing God's direct judgment on Egypt
Pharaoh's hardening of heart (v.12) is not a sudden change but a progression of sin (from v.6 onward)
The hail (v.11) is described as the worst in Egypt's history - this emphasizes God's power over nature

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does God's protection of His people (like the livestock spared) challenge your view of God's judgment? What can you do this week to trust in His protection?
tips: When faced with trials, remember that God protects His people (like the Israelites) even when others suffer
Pray for the courage to trust God's protection in your current situation
Consider an area where you feel judged (like the plagues) and ask God to show you His protection

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about God's protection and Pharaoh's hardening heart. Ask for the courage to repent and trust in God's provision.
tips: Thank God that He protects His people from the plagues of the world
Pray for the strength to repent when you harden your heart
Ask God to help you trust in His provision when you face trials

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Exodus 10:1-29 aloud, focusing on the progression from the locust plague (vv.1-10) to the darkness plague (vv.21-29).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Pharaoh' and the phrase 'hardened his heart' in verses 1, 9, and 21
Pay attention to the emotional shift from Pharaoh's initial reluctance (v.1-5) to his final refusal (v.24-29)
Listen for the contrast in language: 'darkness' (v.22) vs. 'light' (v.23)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is affected, WHAT God does, WHERE it happens, and WHY God is acting in this chapter.
tips: Include Pharaoh's servants urging him to let Israel go (v.11)
Note the locusts devouring what the hail left (v.10)
Highlight the three days of darkness (v.22-23) and Pharaoh's offer to let Israel go without livestock (v.24-25)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Which part stood out most? Consider: the locusts devouring the land (v.1-10), the darkness (v.21-23), or Pharaoh's final demand (v.24-29)?
tips: The locusts: 'They came and covered the land, and the locusts were as numerous as the sand of the sea' (v.10) - shows complete devastation
The darkness: 'The darkness was thick, and the people could not see where they were going' (v.23) - a stark contrast to the light of Israel
Pharaoh's offer: 'Let the people go and they will leave their livestock behind' (v.24) - but Moses refuses, showing the cost of freedom

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God's power and purpose through these plagues?
tips: God's signs are for future generations (v.1) - to show His power over Egypt
The plagues demonstrate God's sovereignty: even when Pharaoh hardens his heart (v.9), God continues His work
The contrast between light (Israel) and darkness (Egypt) pictures the spiritual reality of believers in Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The hardening of Pharaoh's heart? The meaning of darkness? Why God chooses to use plagues?
tips: Pharaoh hardening his heart (v.9) is not a divine choice but a response to God's power - it shows the consequences of rejecting God
The darkness (v.22-23) is not a physical absence of light but a spiritual condition: the Egyptians are in spiritual darkness while Israel has the light of God
The plagues are not random but a series of signs to convince Pharaoh and the Egyptians of God's power (v.1)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'light versus darkness' to your current situation this week?
tips: When you face a decision that seems dark (e.g., fear, confusion), remember that God's light is with you
Pray for the courage to stand in the light when others are in darkness, just as Israel did
Consider if you are 'Pharaoh' - holding on to your own way instead of trusting God's plan

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the light of Christ to shine in your life and for the strength to resist the darkness of fear and doubt.
tips: Thank God for the light that is in you (Christ) while the world is in darkness
Ask for the courage to stand firm in faith when others are confused or fearful
Pray that Pharaoh's heart (your own heart) will not harden against God's leading

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Exodus 12:1-49 aloud, paying attention to the specific instructions for the Passover meal in verses 1-14 and the blood on doorposts in verses 12-13.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'this day' (v.1, 10, 11) emphasizing the importance of the day
Pay attention to the phrase 'the blood of the lamb' (v.12, 13) as the key sign
Notice the urgency in the instructions: 'you shall eat it' (v.14) and 'do not leave any' (v.15)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is instructed, WHAT the Israelites must do, WHERE this happens (in Egypt), and WHY it is done (to be delivered from Egypt's judgment).
tips: Include that the blood is placed on the doorposts to mark the house (v.12-13)
Note that the meal is eaten with unleavened bread and bitter herbs (v.8-10)
Describe the consequence: the death of the firstborn of Egypt (v.29-30)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the blood on doorposts (v.12-13), the haste of the Israelites (v.11), or the instruction to eat the lamb with unleavened bread (v.8-10)?
tips: The blood on the doorposts is a sign that God passes over the house (v.13) - it's a direct link to redemption
The haste of the Israelites (v.11) shows their readiness to leave Egypt immediately after the Passover
The instruction to eat the lamb with unleavened bread and bitter herbs (v.8-10) symbolizes their haste and the bitterness of slavery

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God's plan for their deliverance through the Passover?
tips: The Passover is a sign that God will protect His people from the judgment of the firstborn of Egypt
The blood of the lamb is the means of redemption from slavery
This event establishes the covenant between God and the Israelites (v.48)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The requirement for the blood on doorposts, the timing of the lamb's slaughter, or the concept of the Passover as a type of Christ?
tips: The blood on doorposts: This was a sign that the house was protected from the angel of death, but it required the Israelites to be in a specific location and follow instructions precisely
The timing: The lamb must be killed at twilight (v.12) and the meal eaten that same night, showing urgency
The Christ connection: The Passover lamb is a type of Christ (1 Cor 5:7) - the blood of Christ redeems from sin

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be ready for God's deliverance in your life, like the Israelites were ready for the Passover?
tips: Reflect on what you need to 'haste' toward (v.11) - perhaps a spiritual battle or time of testing
Consider how the blood of the lamb (v.12) represents God's provision - are you trusting Christ for redemption?
Practice being ready: Ensure you have the right spiritual 'unleavened bread' for God's deliverance

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the Passover and ask for the same protection from the angel of death (the enemy) in your life.
tips: Thank God for Christ's blood that protects us from final judgment
Pray for courage to be ready for God's deliverance
Ask God to help you apply the Passover: be quick to trust Him and not delay

tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the firstborn of your sons' (v.12) and 'the firstborn of your livestock' (v.13) to emphasize the scope
Pay attention to the contrast between the Israelites' past in Egypt (v.11) and the present consecration (v.12-14)
The phrase 'This is to be a perpetual memorial' (v.16) is key

questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Israelites) does WHAT (consecrates firstborn and establishes the Feast of Unleavened Bread) WHERE (in the wilderness after leaving Egypt) and WHY (to remember God's deliverance and His ownership of firstborn).
tips: Include the command to consecrate firstborn (sons and livestock) as belonging to God
Note the establishment of the Feast of Unleavened Bread as a perpetual memorial
Mention God's guidance through the wilderness (v.17-19) as a contrast to the short route to Canaan

tips: The phrase 'the firstborn of your sons' (v.12) emphasizes that this is a communal responsibility
The pillar of cloud and fire (v.19) is a powerful image of God's presence leading the way
The command to teach children about the exodus (v.17) is a practical application that connects the past to the present

tips: Moses is emphasizing that God is the ultimate owner of the firstborn (both human and animal) and that this consecration is a memorial of the exodus
The wilderness journey (v.17-19) shows that God is not leading them by the short route (which would have been a quick path to Canaan) but through a process of testing and formation
God's presence (pillar of cloud/fire) is the guarantee of His active guidance

questions.title: Summary

questions.title: Best Bit

The Egyptians' confusion (v.22) is not just physical but also a spiritual confusion, showing that God's judgment is both physical and spiritual

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can the Red Sea crossing apply to your current situation? Consider: when you face a crisis that seems insurmountable, what does God's parting of the sea teach you?
tips: In your current season of difficulty, ask God to part the 'sea' (the obstacle) for you
Remember that God fights for you (v.15) so you don't have to do the heavy lifting
Pray for the courage to cross the dry ground (v.21) in your current crisis

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about God's deliverance in the Red Sea. Thank Him for being your parting and your salvation.
tips: Thank God for parting the way for you in your life (v.21)
Pray for the strength to cross the dry ground (v.21) in your current crisis
Ask God to use the Red Sea event as a reminder that He is the one who fights for you (v.15)

chapters.chapterTitle: The Song of Moses; Bitter Water Sweetened

Listen for the joyful dancing of Miriam and the women (v.20-21)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Israelites and Moses) does WHAT (sings a song of victory and tests the water), WHERE (the wilderness after the Exodus), and WHY (to celebrate God's deliverance and provision).
tips: Include the song of Moses (v.1-19) as a response to God's victory over Egypt
Note the water event at Marah (v.22-23) where God makes the water sweet
Mention the provision at Elim (v.24-27) with twelve springs and seventy palm trees

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the song (v.1-19), Miriam's leadership (v.20-21), or the water event (v.22-27)?

Miriam's dancing with the women (v.20-21) - a communal celebration of God's victory
The turning of bitter water to sweet (v.23-25) - a tangible sign of God's provision and healing

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God through this passage?
tips: To affirm God as the deliverer and provider in the wilderness
To show that God's victory is not only in battle but also in daily provision and healing
To establish the song as a memorial of God's faithfulness for future generations

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The song's meaning? Why God tests the water? The significance of Elim?

The twelve springs and seventy palm trees at Elim (v.27) represent God's abundant provision and healing

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of God's provision and healing. What situation requires you to trust God's provision this week?
tips: Consider a time when you've been in a situation of hardship (like bitter water) and God turned it to sweetness
Practice gratitude by listing three things God has provided for you this week
Ask God to turn your current 'bitter water' into sweet provision

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His victory and provision. Ask for courage to trust Him in your current difficulties.
tips: Thank God for turning your bitter circumstances into sweet provision
Pray for the strength to trust God's provision when you are in the wilderness
Ask God to help you remember His victory over Egypt and His provision in the wilderness

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Exodus 16:1-20 aloud, focusing on the Israelites' complaint and the promise of manna in verses 1-4.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'we have no food' in verses 1-2
Pay attention to the phrase 'the Lord will provide' (v.4) and the specific timing of the manna (daily)
Listen for the emotional shift from complaint to trust in God's provision

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Israelites) is tested, WHAT (God provides manna and quail), WHERE (wilderness), WHEN (after the Exodus), and WHY (to test obedience and ensure they don't return to Egypt).
tips: Include the 40-year duration of manna consumption
Note that the Israelites were to gather manna each day and rest on the seventh
Describe the consequence of disobedience (spoiled manna)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Israelites' complaint (v.1-2), the promise of manna (v.4), the double portion on the sixth day (v.19), or the consequence of gathering on the seventh day (v.20).
tips: The double portion on the sixth day (v.19) shows God's provision for rest and the importance of Sabbath
The phrase 'if they gathered on the seventh day, it was spoiled' (v.20) illustrates the cost of disobedience
The omer (v.18) as a memorial for the day of manna is a tangible reminder of God's provision

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God's provision and obedience through this passage?
tips: God provides daily and sustains His people through the wilderness, but obedience is required (daily gathering, not storing)
The 40 years of manna test their faith and prevent them from forgetting God's provision
The Sabbath rest (seventh day) is a sign of God's provision and the need for rest

questions.title: Difficulties

The omer (a specific measure) was kept as a memorial to remind the people of God's provision in the wilderness

questions.title: Application

tips: Identify one area where you might be hoarding (storing) resources instead of gathering (trusting) God's provision

Keep a small measure (like a portion) as a memorial of God's provision

questions.title: Prayer

tips: Thank God for providing for you in the midst of your struggles

chapters.chapterTitle: Water from the Rock; Battle with Amalek

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Exodus 17:1-16 aloud, focusing on the emotional tension in verses 1-7 and the physical struggle in verses 14-16.
tips: Note the repetition of 'water' in verses 1-2 (v.1: 'there was no water', v.2: 'they quarreled with Moses')
Pay attention to the phrase 'nearly ready to stone him' (v.4) which shows their anger
The command to strike the rock is in verse 8: 'strike the rock'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Israelites and Moses), WHAT (the Israelites' water crisis and God's command to strike the rock, followed by the battle with Amalek), WHERE (Rephidim), and WHY (God's provision of water and the need for intercession in battle).
tips: Include the Israelites' near-stoning of Moses (v.4)
Note Moses striking the rock at Horeb (v.8-9) to get water
Moses' hands are upheld by Aaron and Hur during the battle with Amalek (v.11-13)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the water crisis (v.1-7), the striking of the rock (v.8-9), or the battle with Amalek (v.14-16)?
tips: The water crisis: 'the Israelites were thirsty and there was no water' (v.1) shows their desperation
The rock striking: 'Moses struck the rock and water flowed' (v.8) - a direct command from God
The battle: Moses' hands upheld by Aaron and Hur (v.11) shows corporate support in crisis

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God's provision in trials and the importance of intercession?
tips: God provides living water (like Christ) when we are in crisis
Intercession (Moses' hands) is crucial for victory in battle
The Israelites' testing of God (v.1-7) and God's response (v.8-9)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The water crisis, the rock striking, or the battle with Amalek?
tips: Why did God command Moses to strike the rock? (Note: In Exodus 17:7, the Israelites were already at Rephidim and the rock was already there)
The term 'Horeb' (v.8) is the same as Mount Sinai in some contexts, but here it's the place of the rock
The battle with Amalek: why did God vow perpetual war? (v.16) - because Amalek was a persistent enemy

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of corporate support in battle (v.14-16) - what can you do this week to support others in a difficult situation?
tips: Identify one person who is struggling and offer practical help
Ask a friend to support you when you feel tired (like Aaron and Hur supporting Moses)
Pray for the strength to be a helper in others' battles

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for providing water in times of crisis and ask for the strength to intercede for others.
tips: Thank God for Christ as the living water (1 Cor 10:4)
Pray for the courage to be a helper in others' battles
Ask God to strengthen your hands (intercession) when they tire

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Exodus 18:1-27 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Jethro and Moses in verses 18-20 and the description of Moses' judging in verses 1-10.
tips: Note the phrase 'I have been alone' in verse 16 (Moses' burden)
Pay attention to Jethro's blessing of the LORD in verse 22
Notice the repetition of 'judges' in verses 21-22

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it takes place, and WHY it matters to the Israelites.
tips: Include Jethro bringing Zipporah and Moses' sons (v.2)
Note Moses judging the people alone from morning to evening (v.1-10)
Describe Jethro's advice on delegating to capable men (v.19-20)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jethro's recognition of God (v.22), the delegation system (v.21-22), or Moses' burden (v.16)?
tips: Jethro's blessing of the LORD shows his testimony to God's works in the wilderness
The system of judges (thousands, hundreds, fifties, tens) is a sustainable model for leadership
Moses' admission of being overwhelmed ('I have been alone') reveals the need for shared leadership

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God and leadership through this passage?
tips: God's work in the wilderness requires sustainable leadership that involves others
True leadership is not about isolation but about delegation and shared responsibility
Jethro's recognition of God as the true provider foreshadows the inclusion of Gentiles in God's people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The system of judges? Why Jethro was in the wilderness? The role of Moses' sons?
tips: The term 'delegates' (v.21) refers to assigning authority to capable men, not just passing tasks
Jethro's presence in the wilderness (v.1) shows he was not part of the Israelite community but a wise outsider
The system of judges (thousands, hundreds, fifties, tens) is a practical way to handle cases without Moses being overwhelmed

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you implement the delegation of authority (from this passage) in your current leadership role this week?
tips: Identify one area where you are doing too much and delegate to a trusted team member
Practice listening to others' perspectives before making decisions
Reflect on how you can share leadership responsibilities without losing accountability

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the wisdom of Jethro's advice and ask for the courage to delegate in your leadership.
tips: Thank God for the blessing of wise counsel from others
Pray for the strength to release control and trust others with authority
Ask God to help you see the need for shared leadership in your community

Note the people's fear and request for Moses to speak (v.21)

The role of Moses as mediator (v.22) is crucial because the people are too afraid to approach God directly

Pray for courage to step into obedience as Moses did, knowing God is with you

tips: Thank God for the Ten Commandments that reveal His character
Ask for the courage to obey God's commands without fear
Pray for Christ to be the ultimate mediator between God and you

Pay attention to the phrase 'eye for eye' (v.24) as a model of proportional justice
The phrase 'he that smote his father' (v.15) shows the severity of breaking family bonds

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (God) gives WHAT (laws) to the Israelites, WHERE (in the land of Canaan), and WHY (to establish justice and protect the vulnerable).
tips: Include the law for Hebrew servants (release in the seventh year) in verses 1-6
Note the protection for female servants in verses 7-11
Mention the principle of proportional punishment (eye for eye) in verses 12-13

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the law about servants (v.1-6), the principle of proportional punishment (v.12-13), or the penalty for striking parents (v.15-16)?
tips: The law requiring release of Hebrew servants after six years (v.2) shows God's care for the poor

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God's justice through these laws?
tips: God's concern for the oppressed and vulnerable is central
These laws establish a society where justice is proportional and human life is precious
The laws point to a deeper truth: God's justice is rooted in love and mercy

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The distinction between murder and manslaughter, the cultural context of slavery, or the meaning of 'eye for eye'?
tips: 'Eye for eye' (v.24) is not literal vengeance but proportional punishment; it's a model for justice

The prohibition against selling a Hebrew slave (v.26) shows that God values the person, not just the slave

questions.title: Application

Think about how you can protect the vulnerable in your community (e.g., family, neighbors)
Pray for the strength to be just without being vengeful

questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the laws that protect the vulnerable and ask for the courage to be just.
tips: Thank God for the laws that protect the poor and vulnerable
Ask for the courage to be just in your relationships
Pray for a community where the oppressed are protected

questions.instruction: Read Exodus 22:1-23 aloud, paying attention to the legal structure and the emotional tone of the laws for the vulnerable.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'if a man' (v.1, v.3, v.4) to see the legal pattern
Pay attention to the phrase 'God will hear their cry' (v.22) which shows God's active care for the marginalized
Listen for the urgency in 'return the pledged garments before night' (v.26)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is affected, WHAT the laws address, WHERE they apply, and WHY they are important for the Israelites.
tips: Include the three vulnerable groups: foreigners, widows, and orphans (v.22)
Note the command to lend without interest to the poor (v.25)
Mention the requirement to return pledged garments before night (v.26)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the promise of God hearing their cry (v.22), the urgency of returning pledged garments (v.26), or the prohibition against cursing rulers (v.27).
tips: The phrase 'God will hear their cry' (v.22) is a powerful reminder that God is personally involved in the struggles of the marginalized
Returning pledged garments by night (v.26) shows the immediate care for the poor who might be without shelter
The command not to curse rulers (v.27) reflects respect for God's authority in the community

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God's care for the vulnerable through these laws?
tips: Consider the context of the Israelites entering the Promised Land and the need for a just society
Think about how God's law reflects His heart for the marginalized, which is a key theme in the Old Testament
Note that the laws are not just about rules but about God's active protection for the vulnerable

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The distinction between theft and damage, the meaning of pledged garments, and the prohibition against cursing rulers.
tips: 'Theft' (v.1) refers to taking property without permission, while 'liability for damage' (v.4) is about damage caused by an animal or object in ancient Near Eastern law
Pledged garments (v.26) are items that were pledged as security for a loan; the law requires returning them by night to prevent the poor from going without
The prohibition against cursing rulers (v.27) means not using curses to harm the leaders, which is a sign of respect for God's authority in the community

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, take a concrete step to care for a vulnerable person (widow, orphan, or foreigner) as modeled in Exodus 22.
tips: Identify one vulnerable person in your community and check on them this week
Remember the command to return pledged items by night: if you have a loan agreement, make sure to return it promptly
Pray for the courage to be a protector for the vulnerable in your daily life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's protection over the vulnerable and for the courage to live out the law of care.
tips: Thank God for the law that protects the vulnerable and for His heart for the marginalized
Ask for the strength to be a protector for widows, orphans, and foreigners in your community
Pray for the courage to speak up when someone is being mistreated or when rulers are unjust

tips: Notice the repetition of 'according to all that I show you' (v.40) showing God's direct instruction
Emotional tone: Awe and reverence in the description of the tabernacle's construction
Repeated phrase: 'Make me a tabernacle' (v.1) and 'the ark of the covenant' (v.10) emphasize God's dwelling

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is instructed, WHAT they are to build, WHERE it will be used, and WHY God requires these specific offerings.
tips: Moses receives instructions from God for building the tabernacle
Key elements: gold, silver, bronze, fabrics, skins, wood, oil, spices, and precious stones
The purpose is to create a dwelling place for God's presence

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the detailed instructions for the ark (v.10-22), the table for the bread of presence (v.23-30), or the anointing of the tabernacle (v.30-40)?
tips: The mercy seat with cherubim (v.18-22) symbolizes God's meeting place and atonement
The bread of presence (v.23-29) shows God's ongoing presence in the community
The anointing of the tabernacle (v.30-40) signifies God's acceptance of the people's offerings

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God's dwelling and their relationship with Him through this passage?
tips: God requires a holy space for His presence, reflecting the need for purification and dedication
The offerings show the Israelites' willingness to give of themselves to dwell with God
The ark as the meeting place foreshadows Christ as the true meeting place

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The specific measurements? The role of the mercy seat? Why the table for bread of presence?
tips: The detailed measurements (v.1-9) might be confusing without understanding the context of the tabernacle's purpose
The mercy seat (v.18-22) is where God meets with Moses, but it's also the place of atonement - this dual role is complex
The bread of presence (v.23-29) is a regular offering that the priests eat, but it's also a sign of God's ongoing presence in the community

questions.title: Application

tips: Identify one area where you are holding back from giving fully to God
Consider what 'precious stones' (v.33) you can offer to God this week
Pray for the courage to build a space for God's presence in your life

Ask God to help you create a space in your life for His presence

questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God through this passage?
tips: Moses is establishing that God's people can approach Him through the Tabernacle, which includes the altar for sacrifice and the basin for cleansing
The detailed inventory reflects the covenant relationship where the Israelites are accountable to God for their resources
The basin made from women's mirrors shows that God includes all people in the Tabern: not just men

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging to understand in Exodus 38?
tips: The basin made from mirrors: In ancient cultures, mirrors were used for vanity, so this symbolizes a shift from self-centeredness to God-centeredness
The use of bronze for the altar: Bronze is a common material for the Israelites, but it emphasizes the people's contribution to God's work
The inventory: The detailed accounting of resources might seem excessive, but it shows the Israelites' faithfulness to God's covenant

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of the cleansing basin to your life this week?
tips: Seek spiritual cleansing through God's Word and the blood of Christ
Reflect on how you can be a 'mirror' for Christ in your relationships
Practice accountability by being generous with your resources for God's purposes

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the cleansing basin and the women's contribution.
tips: Thank God for the basin that cleanses us through His blood
Ask for the courage to be a 'mirror' for Christ in your life
Pray for the community to be accountable to God and to give generously of their resources

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Exodus 39:1-38 aloud, paying attention to the repeated phrase 'as the LORD commanded' and the detailed descriptions of the garments.
tips: Notice the phrase 'as the LORD commanded' appears multiple times (v. 2, 3, 5, 8, 11, 15, 20, 22, 25, 29, 31, 35, 37) for emphasis on obedience
Pay attention to the emotional tone of the craftsmen working with precision and the final blessing by Moses (v. 40)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the craftsmen and Moses) does WHAT (makes the priestly garments) WHERE (in the tabernacle camp) and WHY (to fulfill God's command for the priests to serve).
tips: Include the completion of the ephod, breastpiece, robe, tunics, turban, and gold plate
Moses receives the completed garments and blesses the workers (v. 40)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the detailed craftsmanship (v. 3), the phrase 'as the LORD commanded' (v. 2, 3), or the blessing by Moses (v. 40)?
tips: The meticulous detail in the breastpiece with twelve stones (v. 8) shows God's intention for the priests to represent the whole community
The phrase 'as the LORD commanded' appears 13 times in the chapter - emphasizing obedience as the foundation of work
Moses blessing the workers (v. 40) shows the completion of the work and God's approval

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God's command and the priesthood through this passage?
tips: God's commands must be followed precisely to maintain the sacredness of the priesthood
The completion of the garments symbolizes the Israelites' readiness to serve God in the tabernacle
Obedience to God's instructions is the basis for God's blessing and the proper functioning of the temple

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The specific measurements for the garments? Why the priestly garments are so detailed? The role of the gold plate inscribed 'Holy to the LORD'?
tips: The 'ephod' (v. 1) is a complex garment with a breastplate and two pendants - the design symbolizes the priest's connection to the people and God
The phrase 'as the LORD commanded' (v. 2) emphasizes that the work is done by human hands but under divine direction - this is a key theme of obedience in the Law
The gold plate inscribed 'Holy to the LORD' (v. 39) shows the priesthood's role as a mediator between God and the people

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the principle of obedience in the details of your work this week?
tips: Identify one task where you can follow instructions precisely (like the priestly garments) to ensure quality and God's approval
Think about how the completion of the work (v. 40) can be a sign of God's blessing on your efforts
Pray for the strength to do your work 'as the LORD commands' without compromise

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the importance of obedience and the blessing of faithful work.
tips: Thank God for the gift of precise obedience in the priesthood
Ask for the courage to follow God's instructions in your daily tasks
Pray for the blessing of completion and God's approval on your work this week

chapters.chapterTitle: The Tabernacle Erected; God's Glory Fills It

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Exodus 40:1-35 aloud, focusing on the detailed instructions for the tabernacle construction and the anointing process.
tips: Note the repeated phrase 'the cloud' in verses 34-35 which signifies God's presence
Pay attention to the anointing of the tabernacle (verses 20-21) and Aaron's sons
Notice the transition from construction to divine presence (verses 34-35)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (Moses) does WHAT (erects the tabernacle, anoints everything), WHERE (the Tent of Meeting), and WHY (to establish a place for God's presence with the Israelites).
tips: Include the completion of the tabernacle construction and anointing by Moses
Note that the cloud covers the tent and the glory fills it, making Moses unable to enter
Mention that the cloud then guides the Israelites' journeys

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the cloud covering the tent (v.34), the glory filling the tabernacle (v.34-35), or the anointing of the tabernacle (v.20-21)?
tips: The cloud covering the tent (v.34) shows God's immediate presence without human effort
The glory filling the tabernacle (v.35) is a powerful sign of God's dwelling with His people
The anointing (v.21) symbolizes the consecration of the tabernacle and its purpose

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God's presence through the tabernacle?
tips: This passage shows that God's presence is active and tangible in the midst of His people
The tabernacle becomes a place where the Israelites can encounter God, and the glory filling it signifies God's dwelling with them
The cloud as a guide for their journeys emphasizes God's leadership and provision

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this chapter are challenging? The construction process? The glory filling the tabernacle? The cloud's role as a guide?
tips: The detailed construction process (verses 1-29) might be overwhelming for modern readers, but it shows the Israelites' commitment to God's design
The term 'glory' (Hebrew: kavod) refers to God's majestic presence, not a physical object but a spiritual reality
The cloud as a guide (v.35) is a sign that God is actively leading the Israelites, which might be difficult to grasp without the context of wilderness travel

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's glory filling your life this week? Consider a place where you need God's presence to be active.
tips: Set aside a specific time each day for prayer and reflection, as the tabernacle was a dedicated space
Trust God's guidance in your decisions, just as the cloud guided the Israelites
Anoint your heart with the oil of the Holy Spirit (Romans 12:11) to be a living temple

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's presence to fill your life as the glory filled the tabernacle.
tips: Thank God for His presence in your life through the Holy Spirit
Ask for the courage to live in the light of His glory
Pray for the cloud of God's presence to guide you in your daily decisions
